items.question: Persistent vegetative state/no discernible consciousness at time of assessment

answers.label: E
answers.text: Not attempted due to environmental constraints

answers.label: M
answers.text: Not attempted due to medical condition

answers.label: S
answers.text: Not attempted due to safety concerns
Partial/moderate assistance – Helper does LESS THAN HALF the effort. Helper lifts, holds or supports trunk or limbs, but provides less than half the effort.
Setup or clean-up assistance – Helper SETS UP or CLEANS UP; patient completes activity. Helper assists only prior to or following the activity.
Substantial/maximal assistance – Helper does MORE THAN HALF the effort. Helper lifts or holds trunk or limbs and provides more than half the effort.
Supervision or touching assistance – Helper provides VERBAL CUES or TOUCHING/ STEADYING assistance as patient completes activity. Assistance may be provided throughout the activity or intermittently.
Dependent – Helper does ALL of the effort. Patient does none of the effort to complete the task.
Independent – Patient completes the activity by him/herself with no assistance from a helper.

answers.label: E
answers.text: Not attempted due to environmental constraints

answers.label: M
answers.text: Not attempted due to medical condition

answers.label: S
answers.text: Not attempted due to safety concerns
Partial/moderate assistance – Helper does LESS THAN HALF the effort. Helper lifts, holds or supports trunk or limbs, but provides less than half the effort.
Setup or clean-up assistance – Helper SETS UP or CLEANS UP; patient completes activity. Helper assists only prior to or following the activity.
Substantial/maximal assistance – Helper does MORE THAN HALF the effort. Helper lifts or holds trunk or limbs and provides more than half the effort.
Supervision or touching assistance – Helper provides VERBAL CUES or TOUCHING/ STEADYING assistance as patient completes activity. Assistance may be provided throughout the activity or intermittently.
Dependent – Helper does ALL of the effort. Patient does none of the effort to complete the task.
Independent – Patient completes the activity by him/herself with no assistance from a helper.

items.question: Lying to Sitting on Side of Bed

answers.label: M
answers.text: Not attempted due to medical condition

answers.label: S
answers.text: Not attempted due to safety concerns
Partial/moderate assistance – Helper does LESS THAN HALF the effort. Helper lifts, holds or supports trunk or limbs, but provides less than half the effort.
Setup or clean-up assistance – Helper SETS UP or CLEANS UP; patient completes activity. Helper assists only prior to or following the activity.
Substantial/maximal assistance – Helper does MORE THAN HALF the effort. Helper lifts or holds trunk or limbs and provides more than half the effort.
Supervision or touching assistance – Helper provides VERBAL CUES or TOUCHING/ STEADYING assistance as patient completes activity. Assistance may be provided throughout the activity or intermittently.
Dependent – Helper does ALL of the effort. Patient does none of the effort to complete the task.
Independent – Patient completes the activity by him/herself with no assistance from a helper.
Occasionally incontinent (one episode of bowel incontinence)
Frequently incontinent (2 or more episodes of bowel incontinence, but at least one continent bowel movement)
Not rated, resident had an ostomy or did not have a bowel movement for the entire 7 days
Peripheral vascular disease (PVD) or peripheral arterial disease (PAD)

items.question: Height & weight
Does the resident have one or more unhealed pressure ulcer(s) at Stage 1 or higher?
Current number of unhealed (non-epithelialized) pressure ulcers at each stage - Long term care hospital
Number of pressure ulcers at assessment - stage 1
Number of these Stage 2 pressure ulcers that were present upon admission/reentry
Date of oldest stage 2 pressure ulcer
Number of pressure ulcers at assessment - stage 3
Number of these Stage 3 pressure ulcers that were present upon admission/reentry
Number of pressure ulcers at assessment - stage 4
Number of these Stage 4 pressure ulcers that were present upon admission/reentry
Number of unstageable pressure ulcers due to non-removable dressing/device
Number of these unstageable pressure ulcers that were present upon admission/reentry
Number of unstageable pressure ulcers due to coverage of wound bed by slough and/or eschar
Number of these unstageable pressure ulcers that were present upon admission/reentry
Number of unstageable pressure ulcers with suspected deep tissue injury in evolution
Number of these unstageable ulcers that were present upon admission/reentry
Dimensions of unhealed stage 3 or 4 pressure ulcers or eschar - LTCH
Most Severe Tissue Type for Any Pressure Ulcer

answers.text: Epithelial Tissue - new skin growing in superficial ulcer. It can be light pink and shiny, even in persons with darkly pigmented skin.
Granulation Tissue - pink or red tissue with shiny, moist, granular appearance
Slough - yellow or white tissue that adheres to the ulcer bed in strings or thick clumps, or is mucinous
Necrotic Tissue (Eschar) - black, brown, or tan tissue that adheres firmly to the wound bed or ulcer edges, may be softer or harder than surrounding skin.
